question: Why do wolves howl?
answer: Yes, wolves howl to communicate with other wolves. They use howls to assemble the pack, pass on alarms, signal their location, and reinforce social bonds. Wolves may also bark-howl by adding a brief bark
contexts: Context: . Wolves also growl at other wolves while being aggressively dominant. Wolves bark when nervous or when they want to warn other wolves of danger  . Wolves bark very discreetly, and will not generally bark loudly or repeatedly as dogs do; rather, they use a low-key, breathy "whuf" sound to immediately get attention from other wolves. Wolves also "bark-howl" by adding a brief howl to the end of a bark  . Wolves bark-howl for the same reasons they normally bark.
